;;玛丽亚·科里娜·马查多上周收到一份文件，宣布她是委内瑞拉加拉加斯内部反对派选举的获胜者.
;

;上周日，玛丽亚·科里纳·马查多 (María Corina Machado) 以压倒性优势当选，在预计于 2024 年举行的总统竞选中与总统尼古拉斯·马杜罗 (Nicolás Maduro) 较量后，委内瑞拉最高法院暂停了政治反对派初选结果。

;

;法院——由马杜罗的盟友组成——还批准了马查多和另外两人的竞选公职禁令。

;

;周一的裁决是对马查多资格产生怀疑的最新努力，可能会激起人们的愤怒。美国的反应是，本月早些时候解除了对委内瑞拉的制裁，以换取政府承诺在欧洲观察员监督下举行公平的选举。

;

;这是在委内瑞拉总检察长;上周宣布初选，在没有政府参与的情况下独立进行，因金融犯罪和阴谋而受到调查。

;

;马查多赢得了超过 90% 的选票 ;选民投票率高于预期;，分析师预测她可能会击败马杜罗在公平的竞争中。

;
;

;;相关：;;“他们最后的希望”：委内瑞拉的政治挑战者能否让该国摆脱混乱？;

;
;

;危机组织安第斯地区高级分析师菲尔·冈森 (Phil Gunson) 表示，通过认为马查多的选举具有欺诈性，查维斯塔政府可以对这位前立法者的竞选资格提出进一步质疑，同时辩称她的禁令问题无关紧要。

;

;“这实际上根本没有任何法律或法律依据，”冈森说。

;

;反对派领导人拒绝了针对初选程序的指控，并表示他们将支持选择马查多为总理反对派候选人。

;

;“我重申我对[初选]及其伴随的技术团队的支持，”;推文;委内瑞拉国民议会议员德尔莎·索洛扎诺(Delsa Solorzano)。 “委内瑞拉表达了自己的观点，没有什么可以改变一个想要变革的国家的意愿。”

;

;腐败和经济管理不善，再加上石油制裁，已迫使超过 700 万人逃离委内瑞拉严重的粮食短缺、恶性通货膨胀和滚动。过去十年停电。

;

;尽管马杜罗通过操纵选举、贿赂军事干部和以侵犯人权的行为恐吓政治反对派而垮台，但仍保留了对国家的控制。

;

;最高法院Gunson 表示，这一裁决可能会进一步分裂想要参加 2024 年选举的人和想要抵制选举的人之间的分歧。 “投票是浪费时间。”他补充道。

;

;最高法院已下令反对派在三天内上交与选举有关的所有文件，包括候选人登记和所有选民记录，以便选举委员会可以调查这些指控。

;

;反对派担心这些文件可能会被用来迫害反对派并危及明年的选举。

;

;“这明显违反了政府与巴巴多斯反对派签署的协议以及政治危机的彻底升级，”大西洋理事会高级研究员杰夫拉姆齐说。 “马杜罗的表现就好像他并不关心美国可能取消制裁的前景。”

;

; Tue, 31 Oct 2023 04:22:01 +0800 Deforestation has big impact on regional temperatures, study of Brazilian Amazon showshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/30/deforestation-has-big-impact-on-regional-temperatures-study-of-brazilian-amazon-shows
;;2023-10-30T19:40:26Z;
;
;;亚马逊雨林中因种植大豆而引发的森林火灾和森林砍伐的鸟瞰图
;

;森林砍伐造成了根据对巴西亚马逊地区的一项新研究，农业企业将成为森林保护的最大受益者之一。该论文具有重要的政治意义，因为亚马逊流域的农民到目前为止，各州在森林破坏方面一直处于领先地位，因为他们假设他们可以通过清理更多土地来赚钱。

;

;这项新研究凸显了情况的另一面。它显示，如果森林砍伐继续以近年来的快速速度持续下去，到 2050 年，马托格罗索州的农业中心地带的农作物已经遭受干旱和极端高温，气温将升高半摄氏度多一点。

;

;论文;周一发表在《美国国家科学院院刊》;上，证明亚马逊森林砍伐导致变暖距离最远 60 英里。森林砍伐量越大，温度越高。这是对全球变暖更广泛的气候影响的补充。

;
;

;;相关：;;“我们的世界命悬一线”：原住民活动家要求美国农业巨头停止破坏亚马逊雨林;

;
;

;利兹大学的 Dominick Spracklen 表示，平均一棵树的冷却效果相当于每天每小时全功率运行的两到三台 2.5kW 空调。这是通过蒸散作用发挥作用的，他说这与人类为降低体温而产生的汗水非常相似。他说，这种影响的传播范围比任何人想象的都要大。

;

;“我们一直认为这可能会发生，但程度比我想象的要大，”他说。 “我们越来越多地展示森林给周边地区带来的巨大好处。对于农民来说，它们带来了凉爽的空气和更多的降雨。希望用数字来说明这些好处将有助于说服更广泛的人保护森林地区。”

;

;越来越多的同行评审研究证明了亚马逊在维持稳定的区域气候方面的重要性。今年早些时候，;一篇论文表明森林砍伐减少了 125 英里外的降雨量;。最近，更大规模的研究表明，亚马逊与南美季风相结合，;持续的森林砍伐可能使区域降水量减少 30%;，对粮食生产造成可怕的后果。

;

;到目前为止，研究表明关于森林砍伐对热量影响的研究集中于局部影响，树木覆盖范围的丧失与树木被砍伐地区的较高气温之间存在明显的相关性。这项新研究进一步探讨了是否在更大范围内也存在变暖效应。利用卫星数据和人工智能，作者发现 60 英里半径内森林每减少 10 个百分点，气温就会升高 0.7 摄氏度。

;

;在已大面积砍伐的地区，影响是大量。正如论文的结论：“我们表明，区域森林丧失使变暖加剧了四分之多，对剩余的亚马逊森林和居住在那里的人们造成了严重后果。”主要作者埃德·巴特强调，然而，这不应被视为警报，而应被视为激励森林可持续管理的有用工具。 “如果我们能够减少森林砍伐，那么我们就可以在很大程度上避免区域变暖。我认为这是一个很大的机会。它展示了减少森林砍伐给当地农民带来的巨大好处……最重要的是像马托格罗索州这样的州可以遵循不同的未来。这将控制权交还给地区和州。他们确实可以减少他们所面临的变暖程度。”

; Tue, 31 Oct 2023 03:52:01 +0800 Trump maintains huge Iowa polling lead as Nikki Haley gains groundhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/30/iowa-poll-republicans-trump-nikki-haley
;;2023-10-30T14:51:46Z;
;
;;周日晚上，特朗普在爱荷华州苏城举行的集会上。
;

;唐纳德·特朗普维持了他的立场爱荷华州在关键的早期投票中取得巨大领先;NBC 新闻和《得梅因纪事报》进行了一项重大新民意调查;，但妮基·黑利 (Nikki Haley) 现在成为他最接近的挑战者。

;

;这位美国前总统三个月前在爱荷华州领先 27 个百分点在共和党初选的第一轮投票中，他获得了 43% 的支持。但前南卡罗来纳州州长兼联合国大使黑利的支持率上升了 10 个百分点，达到 16%，与佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯并列第二，后者的竞选活动长期以来一直被视为停滞不前。

;

;没有其他候选人即使在暂停竞选活动的前副总统迈克·彭斯的支持者的第二选择被重新分配之后，得分仍显着。

;
;

;;相关：;;阻止“叛乱分子”特朗普参加 2024 年投票的努力将在法庭上审理;

;
;

;进行这项调查的爱荷华州民意调查专家 J Ann Selzer 表示：“这对唐纳德·特朗普来说是一项很好的民意调查。对于上次民意调查到现在发生的所有事情，他仍然是该领域的主导者，事实上，他的地位比八月份有所提高。”

;

;不过，特朗普的记忆力显然没有改善。 。周日在苏城，;他告诉支持者;：“嗯，非常感谢。向我们做得很好的地方致以诚挚的问候：苏福尔斯。非常感谢你，苏福尔斯。”

;

;州参议员布拉德·扎恩 (Brad Zaun) 小声说道：“这是苏城，不是苏福尔斯。”

;

;特朗普说：“哦……是那个吗？对吗？”

;

;他对人群说：“苏城，让我问你们：有多少人来自苏城？”

;

;特朗普的支持率是 77，但民意调查显示更少美国人认为他太老了，不适合连任 ;想想下个月就将满 81 岁的总统乔·拜登吧。特朗普将拜登的年龄作为他竞选活动的打击对象，但两人都受到密切关注，以免犯错。

;

;在苏城，特朗普吹嘘自己与专制世界领导人的关系，称匈牙利“在乌克兰和乌克兰问题上都处于领先地位”。俄罗斯”。匈牙利与俄罗斯没有边界。

;

;黑莉将外交政策智慧作为她向选民宣传的一部分，出色的辩论表现也帮助她崛起。

;

;在 ;NBC/Register 民意调查;，她从八月份的同一调查显示，德桑蒂斯下降了三位。其他候选人的支持率下降（南卡罗来纳州参议员蒂姆·斯科特从 9% 降至 7%，前新泽西州州长克里斯·克里斯蒂从 5% 降至 4%）或停滞不前（企业家维韦克·拉马斯瓦米保持在 4%）。

;

;海莉是 17% 可能参加党团会议的人的第二选择，还有 22% 的人表示会考虑她。

;

;来自安克尼的 60 岁克里斯蒂·贝克威斯 (Kristy Beckwith) 说：“我觉得她很新鲜，而且我喜欢她所说的……她作为南卡罗来纳州州长所做的事情……她是一位坚强的女性。”

;

;特朗普面临 91 项刑事指控，包括颠覆州和联邦选举以及各种民事审判。尽管如此，他在 NBC/Register 民意调查中的领先优势有所扩大。 8月份，他领先德桑蒂斯23分。他目前领先 27 票。

;

;福音派基督徒仍然是爱荷华州的一个关键投票集团。尽管特朗普因向色情明星支付封口费而面临刑事指控，并因强奸指控而面临民事审判，但法官称“;基本正确;”，NBC/Register 民意调查中 65% 的受访者表示，此类法律问题不会阻止他赢得大选。;全国民意调查平均值;显示特朗普的支持率为 57%：43比德桑蒂斯高 %，比海利高 49%。

; Tue, 31 Oct 2023 03:52:01 +0800 China seeks to stifle public grief for former premier Li Keqianghttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/30/china-seeks-to-stifle-public-grief-for-former-premier-li-keqiang
;;2023-10-30T19:04:32Z;
;
;;人群站着看着一大堆鲜花贡品。
;

;公众向中国致敬周五去世的前总理李克强受到严格控制，政府试图防止大规模哀悼可能导致社会动荡。

;

;李 ;李克强讣告;

; ;

;有公开表达哀悼，;尤其是;在他的家乡安徽省合肥市，数百名哀悼者为其中一人献花

;

;社交媒体上充斥着对李克强的赞扬，李克强曾被视为中国共产党最高层经济自由化的一股力量。但网上的讨论受到了严格审查，以确保李克强的遗产符合官方叙述，并且没有提及有关政治或经济改革的谈话要点。

;

;一份泄露的备忘录，由 ;中国数字时代;，显示媒体已被指示“特别注意“关于李去世的过度热情的评论”。

;

;许多提及李作为经济改革家声誉的评论被删除。一条被微博审查的评论引用了李克强担任总理第一年的一句话：“市场能做的，就让市场做更多。”

; ;

;尽管担任中国总理已有十年，但目前尚不清楚除了定期葬礼安排之外，李克强是否还会收到官方追悼会。在周五的外交部例行新闻发布会上，发言人毛宁拒绝详细说明任何计划。

;

;学生被中共精英视为抗议活动中最不稳定的人群，他们被指示不要超出官方界限的公开展示。社交媒体上流传的;截图;显示，海南大学团委指示学生“最多”分享李的官方讣告。据台湾媒体报道，该通知称“严禁”任何线上或线下聚会。

;

;贵阳航空航天学院向学生张贴的另一张通知要求他们不要发表任何评论关于“政治局势”并避免任何公共集会。

; ;

;2013年李克强就任总理时，他被视为拥抱私营企业、让自由市场蓬勃发展的人。但他逐渐被中国领导人习近平排挤，习近平重申了中共对经济各个领域的控制。对许多人来说，李现在代表了中国日益专制的政府不走的道路。

;

;中共特别担心对高级官员或公众人物死亡的反应。 1976 年前总理周恩来和 1989 年中共前总书记胡耀邦的去世引发了广泛的悲痛，最终演变成抗议活动。

;

;最近，;2020年新冠举报人李文亮;和人们;新疆发生公寓火灾; 2022 年引发了公众悲伤的表达——后者成为“;将公众的悲痛描述为“自白人纸张运动”。

; ;

;瓦瑟斯特罗姆补充道：“某些方面肯定对习近平有很多不满，但在不冒很大风险的情况下表达不满的空间很小……对李的去世表示遗憾至少为以一种隐蔽的方式做到这一点提供了机会。”;

;伦敦大学亚非学院中国研究院院长曾锐生也表示，“深情地怀念李，是对习近平的不快的隐晦表达”。

;

;考虑到这一点，曾荫权表示，“习近平不可能允许李的“除了小家庭事务之外的任何事”。

;加拿大航空一名患有痉挛性脑瘫的男子因旗舰航空公司未能为他提供轮椅而被迫拖下飞机，被迫道歉。

;;2023-10-30T16:00:17Z;
;
;;展出的霸王龙骨架
;

;最终是灰尘造成的恐龙。至少这是对 6600 万年前小行星撞击后的后果进行的计算机模拟发现的结果，这场撞击重塑了地球上的生命。

;

;在墨西哥尤卡坦半岛现在的希克苏鲁伯地区发生的灾难性撞击消灭了 75% 的物种地球上的恐龙，包括非鸟类恐龙。但致命一击的确切性质让科学家们忙碌了数十年，;喷出烟灰的野火;，;火山喷发;和;大量硫磺;所有被认为是罪魁祸首。

;

;在;自然地球科学;中撰写，比利时的研究人员认为，人们对这次撞击所设定的“确切的杀伤机制”仍然知之甚少，而且对暴力事件可能扬起的数万亿吨灰尘的作用也关注得太少。

; < p>;烟灰、硫磺和灰尘在大气中盘旋多年，它们都有能力遮挡阳光，导致全球冬季植被枯竭，对它们赖以生存的动物产生毁灭性的连锁反应。

;

;为了更深入地研究不同因素的作用，科学家们对古代气候进行了模拟，其中考虑了从北达科他州一个地点回收的细颗粒物的测量值，那里有一层由希克苏鲁伯撞击产生的尘埃沉淀。< /p>;

;根据模拟，达科他州发现的这种大小的灰尘在被喷射到天空后可能会在大气中保留长达 15 年。如果阻挡太阳光线，多达 2 万亿吨的二氧化碳可能会导致光合作用停止近两年，并使地球温度降低高达 15 摄氏度。

;

;由撞击地点的花岗岩粉和其他岩石制成布鲁塞尔比利时皇家天文台的研究员杰姆·伯克·塞内尔 (Cem Berk Senel) 表示，这些尘埃“很可能通过破坏光合作用而引发了上一次大规模灭绝事件”。

;

;硅酸盐尘埃出现了该研究的合著者、布鲁塞尔自由大学的地质学家和行星科学家 Philippe Claeys 补充道，从模拟结果来看，它是“最有效的光合作用阻断剂”。 “它使大气对阳光变得不透明，阻碍了植物的光合作用过程。”

;

;根据计算机模型，光合作用需要两年时间才能恢复。

;

;Steve Brusatte爱丁堡大学古生物学和进化论教授没有参与这项研究，他将这颗杀死恐龙的小行星描述为“世界末日”。

;

;他说：“这是撞击的最大小行星the Earth in the last half a billion years, and it detonated with the force of over a billion nuclear bombs put together. But that's not what really killed the dinosaurs and the 75% of other species that died out.

;

;“What really drove their doom was what happened afterwards, as the dust and grime from the asteroid impact went into the atmosphere and blocked out the sun. The Earth went dark and cold for a few years. The asteroid didn't kill all the dinosaurs in one go, but it was a more stealthy murderer, which triggered a war of attrition that led three out of every four species to die.”

;Residents of Lewiston return to work on Monday, the morning after coming together to mourn those lost in ;Maine's worst mass shooting;.

;

;

;
;

;

;

;The vigil came two days after the suspected gunman, Robert Card, was found dead on Friday evening, of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

;

;

;The victims are now gone, he said, “but they are directing us to come together and make a difference in this world.”

;

;The Rev Todd Little from the First United Pentecostal church of Lewiston spoke at the vigil of a diverse community that now has something new in common after the tragedy, talking of “shared brokenness, worry, fear and loss”.

;

;He also vowed that the community was bigger than the tragedy and will emerge not just “Lewiston Strong” but “Lewiston Stronger”.

;

;Meanwhile, Lewiston was slowly reopening. Lewiston schools released a limited schedule for the week “with room for reflection as we move forward”. Only the staff was returning on Monday, students were due back Tuesday. The Lewiston city hall planned to reopen on Monday afternoon.

;Investigators are still searching for a precise motive for the massacre, but have increasingly focused on Card's mental health history.

;

;“It's been a tough few days, trust me. The heart doesn't stop bleeding,” he said.

;The deadliest shootings in Maine's history stunned a state of 1.3 million people that has comparatively little violent crime.

;Four of the 13 injured remain in hospital.

;

;Malawi has seen a resurgence of the infectious skin disease scabies in an outbreak that is being linked to the climate crisis. Just months after a ;cholera outbreak; killed more than 1,800 people and affected a total of 58,982 people in August, the country has seen the return of the disease in the northern city of Mzuzu and the southern Nsanje district, with 4,152 cases registered in the past week.

;

;Scabies is a highly contagious disease caused by tiny mites that burrow into the skin causing intense irritation and discomfort. It is spread through skin to skin contact.

;

;George Mbotwa, the spokesperson for Nsanje district hospital, said the hospital was struggling to cope with the influx of cases. “We registered 4,000 cases across Nsanje district and we are still screening. But the challenge is that we do not have enough medicine to treat the disease. However, we are relying on partnerships with other organisations to help so can we treat people.

;

;“We are doing mass [public] awareness … because this is a disease related to hygiene and hygiene issues also lead to cholera,” he said. “We call on organisations and other partners to come forward to assist us.”

;

;Mbotwa said 1,600 of the 4,000 cases were school-age children.

;

;In Mzuzu, Mzimba North District Health Office spokesperson Lovemore Kawayi said about 152 cases had been registered and an awareness campaign was in place to contain the spread of the disease.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Climate action must respond to extreme weather driving health crisis, says WHO;

;
;

;Health campaigners believe the ;outbreak could be directly linked to the climate crisis;, as the ;current heatwave;, high humidity and water shortages across Malawi make people more vulnerable to disease outbreaks.

;

;Public health expert Maziko Matemba said Malawi needs to do more to address the impact of the climate crisis on health. “Looking at scabies, which has affected Mzuzu city and Nsanje districts, I believe that could be as a result of climate change.

;

;“Climate change and health are very critical for Malawi and we need to do more in terms of climate change negotiations. We need to look at the impacts on people's health to ensure we try as much to avoid these conditions,” said Matemba.

;

;According to WaterAid Malawi, one in three people (;about 5.6 million ;people) in the country do not have access to clean watere. About 3,100 children under five die every year from diarrhoea caused by poor sanitation, it said.

;

;According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's sixth assessment report, climate risks are appearing faster than previously expected, and 3.6 billion people live in areas already highly affected by climate change.

;

;Despite contributing minimally to global emissions, low-income countries and small island developing states endure the harshest health impacts. In vulnerable regions, the death rate from extreme weather events in the past decade was 15 times higher than in less vulnerable ones.

; Tue, 31 Oct 2023 00:22:01 +0800 Climate crisis: carbon emissions budget is now tiny, scientists sayhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/30/climate-crisis-carbon-emissions-budget
;;2023-10-30T16:00:17Z;
;
;;A pumpkin crop in Colorado
;

;The carbon budget remaining to limit the climate crisis to 1.5C of global heating is now “tiny”, according to an analysis, sending a “dire” message about the adequacy of climate action.

;

;The ;carbon budget; is the maximum amount of carbon emissions that can be released while restricting global temperature rise to the limits of the Paris agreement. The new figure is half the size of the budget estimated in 2020 and would be exhausted in six years at current levels of emissions.

;

;;Temperature records have been obliterated; in 2023, with ;extreme weather supercharged by global heating; ;hitting lives; ;and livelihoods; across the world. At the imminent UN Cop28 climate summit in the United Arab Emirates there are likely to be disputes over calls for a phaseout of fossil fuels.

;

;The analysis found the carbon budget remaining for a 50% chance of keeping global temperature rise below 1.5C is about 250bn tonnes. Global emissions are ;expected to reach a record high; this year of about 40bn tonnes. To retain the 50% chance of a 1.5C limit, emissions would have to plunge to net zero by 2034, far faster than even the most radical scenarios.

;

;The current UN ambition is to cut emissions by half by 2030 and reach net zero by 2050, although existing policies are far from delivering this ambition. If it was achieved, however, it would mean only about a 40% chance of staying below 1.5C, the scientists said, so breaking the limit would be more likely than not.

;

;But, they warned, every 10th of a degree of extra heat caused more human suffering and therefore keeping as close as possible to 1.5C was crucial.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Revealed: how climate breakdown is supercharging toll of extreme weather;

;
;

;The new carbon budget estimate is the most recent and comprehensive analysis to date. The main reasons the budget has shrunk so markedly since 2020 are the continued high emissions from human activities and a better understanding of how reducing air pollution increases heating by blocking less sunlight.

;

;Prof Joeri Rogelj, at Imperial College London, UK, and one the study's authors, said: “The budget is so small, and the urgency of meaningful action for limiting warming is so high, [that] the message from [the carbon budget] is dire.

;

;“Having a 50% or higher likelihood that we limit warming to 1.5C is out of the window, irrespective of how much political action and policy action there is.” He said it was “remarkable” how much risk humanity appeared willing to take with global heating.

;

;Dr Chris Smith, at the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Austria, who was also part of the study, said: “Governments can control the emissions but, at the moment, they have not done so. This is why we have an ever-shrinking carbon budget. We are not saying we only have six years to solve climate change – absolutely not. If we are able to limit warming to 1.6C or 1.7C, that's a lot better than 2C. We still need to fight for every 10th of a degree.”

;

;The study, ;published in the journal Nature Climate Change;, used updated data and improved climate modelling compared with other recent estimates. It also used the latest figures showing that aerosol air pollution and the clouds it was helping to seed were better at blocking sunlight and limiting heating than previously thought. As a result, lower pollution in future would mean more global heating and therefore a smaller carbon emissions budget to remain under 1.5C.

;

;The analysis also looked at the 2C upper limit in the Paris agreement, which even if met would still mean a sharp increase in climate impacts from heatwaves to floods to crop losses.

;

;For a 90% chance of keeping below 2C, emissions would have to hit net zero in about 2035, the study found. Achieving net zero in 2050 would give a 66% chance of meeting the 2C target.

;

;Ben Sanderson, at the Centre for International Climate and Environmental Research in Norway, and not part of the study, said the remaining budget for 1.5C was tiny. “The [analysis] makes for uncomfortable reading for policymakers. The budget is consistent with net zero CO;2; emissions being achieved in 2034. This is vastly more ambitious than current implemented global climate policies.”

;

;Dr Gabriel Abrahão, at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research in Germany, said: “There is a very real possibility that we will overshoot the 1.5C target in this decade. Thus, the public debate and the international climate negotiations should already be discussing how to return to 1.5C after an overshoot, so that [it] doesn't end up being permanent.”

;

;The calculation of carbon budget involved significant uncertainties, the researchers said. Sanderson added: “This [updated carbon budget] illustrates that any calculation, no matter how rigorous, is subject to change with revised data and understanding.”

;

;Dr Robin Lamboll, at Imperial College London, said future revisions that increased the carbon budget were “not very likely now”.

;

;Global carbon emissions from ;fossil fuel burning could peak as early as this year;, according to data from the International Energy Agency, meaning they could begin to fall in 2024.

;

;Lamboll said the researchers hoped to produce annual updates on the remaining carbon budgets.
